snippet.textDisplay:
Kinda wish Linus talked more on G-Sync and actually got it to work just for curiosity sake.

I bought the C9 65" from Black Friday and playing games at 120hz is seriously a game changer for me. It's almost like I get a Cinematic experiences like with 30FPS but at a much smoother picture! Run a 1080Ti and as much as I want a 2000 series card to just have G-Sync enabled, it's not worth it since I imagine the value will drop considerably. Especially if the rumors of the 3000 series comes true.

Also can I just say as he was talking about C9 releasing the Update and BFGD Price difference, I had a massive smile on my face. :D
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
LOL LG C9 was better than that garbage washed out contrast expensive monitor you have there with or without Gsync working. And for Gsync you need to install the latest FW on the TV LOL...


In my opinion LG C9 is just the best TV ever until this point (taking out microled and prototypes from the equation and only at this moment in time).


LG C9 is currently here for 1499€ and LG gives 100€ back on the 55 inch model so the LG C9 would cost 1399€ here at the moment for the 55 inch TV and when we get HDMI 2.1 in everything it will surely show it's full potential...



Also the TV has been tested to 6.6 ms at 1440P 120hz, 1080P 120hz 6.8ms by rtings.com which is super damn nice for the super high quality of the TV and actually being a total full monitor plus the response time of the pixels with 80% response time of only 0.2ms is miles away from any LCD without needing huge overdrive garbage which is all fake news as it looks horrible with the artefacts that it causes while everyone keep claiming 1ms and some less on their LCD's which is fake and not normal, my LCD claims 2ms for example but I always use no overdrive, even the faster setting pisses me off with motion and the fastest setting jeez is just trails of ghosting colors all over the place, fake 2ms lol...



The very highest End TV was never this priced so good like at the moment, but soon will go back to like 2500 or 2600€ normal price for the 55 inch :(...

snippet.textDisplay:
Mine will be here Friday. I hope I did well here. Thanks for everything, Linus and team. I’ve built badass computers, bought cool tech, and become a little more intelligent about what I’m buying because of you and your team. I sincerely wish you guys the best in all your current and future endeavors. Have a fantastic holiday season.

Also, if my program takes off in a couple years I become successful, I’m going to hit you up.

Thanks again, and all the best,
Jack

snippet.textDisplay:
OBJECTION. The monitor is 4K in pixels - 2,160 high (by 3,840 wide). The source, says Linus, is 1,440 because of the HDMi limitation. Within each frame, the rendering engine in the display must upsample the source to the display format. It also does noise suppression - very important to keep the blacks clean. That is a lot of calculation. Do not judge latency based on this without this context or you'll get points deducted from the nerd score.
Whilst a frame at 1,080p is 2 megapixel (MP), at 1,440 it is 4. Our ability to see detail has a linear property, meaning it follows the size difference of one side: 1,440 versus 1,080 = 1 1/3. But the image processing relates to the area in pixels: anti-aliasing and noise suppression compare each pixel with its surrounding pixels. The display image (2,180) is extrapolated from the source data (1,440) in processes we call interpolation (read up on "convolution").
We should add that keeping the latency at equal or less than one frame, means there is no time to compare this image with the next, only with the past ones, to help improve noise suppression. 2160p has twice the detail resolution of 1,080p for the human eye. 4K is faced with four times the trouble of image processing of 1K.
If we really want to compare image quality, then we need to make this a multi-dimensional or multi-attribute model: detail resolution (linear size), gradation resolution (bit depth), dynamic range (static, please, at pixel level, please), and color space. That would really give a lot of bonus points to the nerd score.
snippet.textOriginal:
OBJECTION. The monitor is 4K in pixels - 2,160 high (by 3,840 wide). The source, says Linus, is 1,440 because of the HDMi limitation.  Within each frame, the rendering engine in the display must upsample the source to the display format. It also does noise suppression - very important to keep the blacks clean. That is a lot of calculation. Do not judge latency based on this without this context or you'll get points deducted from the nerd score.
Whilst a frame at 1,080p is 2 megapixel (MP), at 1,440 it is 4. Our ability to see detail has a linear property, meaning it follows the size difference of one side: 1,440 versus 1,080 = 1 1/3. But the image processing relates to the area in pixels: anti-aliasing and noise suppression compare each pixel with its surrounding pixels. The display image (2,180) is extrapolated from the source data (1,440) in processes we call interpolation (read up on "convolution").
We should add that keeping the latency at equal or less than one frame, means there is no time to compare this image with the next, only with the past ones, to help improve noise suppression. 2160p has twice the detail resolution of 1,080p for the human eye. 4K is faced with four times the trouble of image processing of 1K.
If we really want to compare image quality, then we need to make this a multi-dimensional or multi-attribute model: detail resolution (linear size), gradation resolution (bit depth), dynamic range (static, please, at pixel level, please), and color space. That would really give a lot of bonus points to the nerd score.

Hey, look, another advertisement for another overpriced free TV trash ! Now with self-destructing OLED.

snippet.textDisplay:
Just because you have instant game response toggled doesn’t mean it’s on. The tv will tell you when it activates. For me it activates with my pc, but it won’t with a switch so I have to put on game mode to get low latency.

I’ve tested the input lag with instant game response in other picture modes. There is no difference between game mode and other picture modes.
snippet.textOriginal:
Just because you have instant game response toggled doesn’t mean it’s on. The tv will tell you when it activates. For me it activates with my pc, but it won’t with a switch so I have to put on game mode to get low latency.

I’ve tested the input lag with instant game response in other picture modes. There is no difference between game mode and other picture modes.

snippet.textDisplay: When you first 'upgraded' to the BFGTV, I wondered wtf you were smoking.  You are never going to get OLED type quality for anything from a set that has a bunch of lights behind it.  It's just a fundamentally superior technology.  There's no real reason aside from driving electronics that input can't be instantaneous.  There's no real reason aside from electronics that it can't do crazy ass framerates.  I don't know if they've even documented an OLED switching time limit like you get with IPS and TN LCD panels.  And contrast ratio is the single largest factor influencing human visual quality, so having it be infinite is just an advantage I wouldn't want to be up against if I was one of the other display manufacturers.
snippet.textOriginal: When you first 'upgraded' to the BFGTV, I wondered wtf you were smoking.  You are never going to get OLED type quality for anything from a set that has a bunch of lights behind it.  It's just a fundamentally superior technology.  There's no real reason aside from driving electronics that input can't be instantaneous.  There's no real reason aside from electronics that it can't do crazy ass framerates.  I don't know if they've even documented an OLED switching time limit like you get with IPS and TN LCD panels.  And contrast ratio is the single largest factor influencing human visual quality, so having it be infinite is just an advantage I wouldn't want to be up against if I was one of the other display manufacturers.

snippet.textDisplay: The BFGD never made any sense to me. I invested in a Sony 65inch A9f OLED and would never ever go back to LED after experiencing true blacks and crisp viewing angles. It boggles my mind that Linus has changed his TV more than 3 times this year alone. I'm all good with reviews but does anyone else feel just a small amount of guilt for the wasted tech on display?

snippet.textDisplay: Linus my man, you have the 2019 LG OLEDs all wrong. I have 3 of them, and their biggest feature is not G-Sync support but the phenomenal motion quality @ 60 Hz w/ Black Frame Insertion. You hate motion blur, so I don't know why you mess with G-Sync, what you want is "OLED Motion" mode enabled to disable G-Sync and instead use BFI. The motion quality is CRT-like and is the reason I own three of these TVs!
snippet.textOriginal: Linus my man, you have the 2019 LG OLEDs all wrong. I have 3 of them, and their biggest feature is _not_ G-Sync support but the phenomenal motion quality @ 60 Hz w/ Black Frame Insertion. You hate motion blur, so I don't know why you mess with G-Sync, what you want is "OLED Motion" mode enabled to disable G-Sync and instead use BFI. The motion quality is CRT-like and is the reason I own three of these TVs!

snippet.textDisplay:
Why haven't affordable OLEDs Monitors come out yet?
Why hasn't LG simply taken the awesome, affordable B-series OLED TVs and l-i-t-e-r-a-l-l-y just scale them down to ~24-36in?

I'm absolutely 100% sold on OLED: true-black, better for the eyes, natural full color spectrum coverage, and potential for ZERO-FLICKER displays and NO headaches!!!
... but
1) I literally don't want that much screen real-estate
2) The thought of dropping $1500 on a "screen" is offensive to my frugality-oriented sensibilities.
3) Dafuq is the point of having 4K if you can't drive all those pixels with your graphics card?

Just gimmie a 1440p + 144hz + ~24in-30in + the 'syncs' + decent pixel response time + decent peak brightness + solid color fidelity + acceptable build quality for ~$350, and I'm fucking sold. Hell, I'll buy two..... and more as Christmas presents!

But miss me with this Middle Class Faux-Luxury Consoomer crap.

I don't need 4K (until the prices for card which can actually drive 4K at acceptable refresh rates come WAY down), I'm a grown-ass adult - I don't need RGB (lol), don't need a fancy stand, don't need "HDR" (every implementation of which is either ultra-expensive, or isn't even actually real HDR), and I DEFINITELY don't need Google Assistant / AI / Roku / any of that spy-crap.
snippet.textOriginal:
Why haven't affordable OLEDs Monitors come out yet?

I'm absolutely 100% sold on OLED: true-black, better for the eyes, natural full color spectrum coverage, and potential for ZERO-FLICKER displays and NO headaches!!!
... but
1) I literally don't want that much screen real-estate
2) The thought of dropping $1500 on a "screen" is offensive to my frugality-oriented sensibilities.
3) Dafuq is the point of having 4K if you can't drive all those pixels with your graphics card?

Just gimmie a 1440p + 144hz + ~24in-30in + the 'syncs' + decent pixel response time + decent peak brightness + solid color fidelity + acceptable build quality for ~$350, and I'm fucking sold. Hell, I'll buy two..... and more as Christmas presents!

But miss me with this Middle Class Faux-Luxury Consoomer crap.

I don't need 4K (until the prices for card which can actually drive 4K at acceptable refresh rates come WAY down), I'm a grown-ass adult - I don't need RGB (lol), don't need a fancy stand, don't need "HDR" (every implementation of which is either ultra-expensive, or isn't even actually real HDR), and I DEFINITELY don't need Google Assistant / AI / Roku / any of that spy-crap.
